UTEID: dtn384; js62724;
FIRSTNAME: Danny; Jenna;
LASTNAME: Nguyen; Saleh;
CSACCOUNT: dannytn; jenna900;
EMAIL: dannytnguyen91@gmail.com; jas009@utexas.edu;

[Program 3]
[Description]
We used 3 java files: Encoder.java, Huffmancode.java, and PairHuffmancode.java. We got the Huffman code from this website:
http://rosettacode.org/wiki/Huffman_coding#Java
In Encoder.java, we initialized a few variables. volume is spcified on the command line and represents the size of the generated texts. It should be a positive and even number. we read the frequencyfile spcified by the first argument on the command line, then used the Huffman encoding algorithm to generate unique bit strings to represent each symbol. we found the entropy of the language then created the text of random characters. We then encoded that file using huffman codes again then wrote it out to a file then fed that file into another file which decoded the information. then we printed a summary of the results including the average number ofbits per symbol and the percent difference of our actual results. We did the same process for the 2 symbol alphabet and compared the efficiency with the 1-symbol alphabet. 
to compile our program, use javac *.java, 
to run it: java Encoder freqencyfile k (where frequencyfile is name of the file and k is the number of characters you want generated)


[Finish]
We finished the whole program. Our only specification/assumption is that K needs to be a positive and EVEN number.


[Test Cases]
[Input of test 1]
[command line]java Encoder freq1 10

[Input file (freq1)]
7
3
4
1
6
7
3
4
6
8
